channel.title: Interleaved RSS Feed
channel.description: This is an interleaved feed of the most recent entries from each RSS source, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: Summer Solstice 2024: Why It’s the Longest Day of the Year
item.description: We have Earth’s off-kilter tilt to thank for the summer solstice, as well as the different seasons.

item.title: Middle East Crisis: Israeli Military Signals Deeper Rift With Netanyahu Over Direction of War
item.description: The chief spokesman of the armed forces said that unless the government advanced a postwar plan for governing Gaza, “We will get Hamas again.”

item.title: Warhammer maker gives its ‘unique, and often quirky’ staff $8,600 each
item.description: Games Workshop is paying $22.9 million to its workers as reward for a double-digit profit boost last year.

item.title: Rain and Floods Hit New Mexico Region Ravaged by Wildfires
item.description: The rain will help control the fires, which have killed two people and scorched more than 23,000 acres. The wildfires were expected to continue burning, the authorities said.

item.title: Russia and North Korea’s Defense Pact Is a New Headache for China
item.description: The treaty raises the risk of confrontation in the region and could prompt the United States and its allies to bolster their military presence on China’s periphery.

item.title: Chinese carmakers are losing their appetite for Europe after the EU imposed tariffs on their EVs
item.description: Over 80% of Chinese vehicle firms are less confident about investing in Europe in the near-term, reports a China Chamber of Commerce to the EU survey.

item.title: Extreme Heat in Rural America, and Putin Visits Vietnam
item.description: Plus, Louisiana and the Ten Commandments.

item.title: Russia and North Korea’s Defense Pact Is a Told-You-So Moment in Asia
item.description: While the agreement rattled officials in South Korea and Japan, the two U.S. allies in recent years have been expecting growing security challenges from North Korea.

item.title: Boeing 737 Max crash victims' families ask the Justice Department to fine the planemaker $25 billion
item.description: That amount is “legally justified and clearly appropriate,” Paul Cassell, an attorney who represents 15 victims’ families, said in a letter sent to the DOJ on Wednesday.

item.title: Russia and North Korea’s Defense Pact Is a New Headache for China
item.description: The treaty raises the risk of confrontation in the region and could prompt the United States and its allies to bolster their military presence on China’s periphery.

item.title: Who Is Ibrahim al-Organi, Accused of Charging Palestinians to Escape Gaza?
item.description: Ibrahim al-Organi has close connections with the Egyptian government, diplomats say, and he has multiple business interests in Gaza.

item.title: Thomson Reuters CEO: AI guardrails remain unclear—but all companies can begin by pledging to protect their customers’ data privacy
item.description: 'We won’t allow a customer’s data to be used to train a third-party LLM,' writes Thomson Reuters CEO Steve Hasker.

item.title: Russia and North Korea’s Defense Pact Is a Told-You-So Moment in Asia
item.description: While the agreement rattled officials in South Korea and Japan, the two U.S. allies in recent years have been expecting growing security challenges from North Korea.

item.title: When the Only Escape From War in Gaza Is to Buy a Way Out
item.description: For many Palestinians, securing approval to exit the territory is possible only after raising thousands of dollars to pay middlemen or an Egyptian company.

item.title: Tropical Storm Alberto—the first named one of the season—leaves 3 dead
item.description: Late Wednesday, Alberto was located about 135 miles east of Tampico, Mexico, and about 320 miles south-southeast of Brownsville, Texas.
